Problem:
Consider a system characterized by a complex function \\( z(t) =  x(t) + iy(t) \\), where \\( x(t) \\) and \\( y(t) \\) are real functions describing a signal's components in time. A Fourier transform \\( F(\\omega) \\) is applied to transform \\( z(t) \\) into the frequency domain.

If we observe a modified time-domain function after applying an inverse Fourier transform, can we definitively trace back and identify the specific filtering process used (i.e., determine \\( G(\\omega) \\)) without prior knowledge about the intervention?
Explanation: Without knowledge of the exact nature of the filtering process or additional data, it is generally impossible to uniquely determine which filter (\\( G(\\omega) \\)) was applied in the frequency domain purely based on the modified time-domain output. Similar filters could produce indistinguishably comparable effects in certain setups.
